awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Next-Generation 3-D Printer for Smart Product Design - Purdue PolymerMakers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, developing an entirely new generation of 3D printers, aims to enable new areas of research into co-design, robotic meta-materials, soft robotics, nano-structures, neuromorphic architectures, and planning. This new generation of 3D printers (Purdue PolymerMaker 3-D Smart Printers) will realize the structure of a prototype (form) in addition to its sensors, computation, and actuation (function) that make it work, ushering a new era of smart product design that will be achieved through a combination of 3-D printing of polymer structure, 2-1/2 D printing of polymer electronics for sensing, computation and actuation, 3-D printing liquid metal interconnect, and automated planning for over-molding of non-polymer components, such as silicon microprocessors and electromagnetic motors. This work relies on the solid work of a large number of researchers in a variety of disciplines. The invention of polymers had a sudden impact on the form of objects designers could design. The invention of polymer 3-D printing has a more dramatic impact on how innovators could realize prototypes of those exciting new forms. The expected next giant leap in polymers and design will be the simultaneous realization of both form and function. Imagine creating an entire smart product prototype at the press of a button!

The deposition of polymers, either as a structure, as active semiconductor, or as activated sensing site, depends on the surface it adheres to, the environment, and the process steps that follow deposition. This project proposes to select and develop automated processes and materials that, when integrated, are carefully selected and tuned to "minimize impedance mismatches" at the interfacial boundaries. The mechatronic integration of precise, closed-loop, motion control for deposition and curing will assure materials are placed when and where needed. Micro-active doctor blading will be employed to locally level the thick extruded liquids. The blade is robotically controlled. 

Broader Impacts:
This new generation of 3-D printers will cut across most fields, allowing social and behavioral scientists to explore new forms of technology, medical and biological experts to print new types of smart assays, educators from "K to Gray" to develop new hands-on activities, and engineers and computer scientists to do their jobs faster and with greater impact. Graduate and undergraduate students will be engaged in new class materials to reach out to K-12 schools with Science, Technology, Engineering, Math-related recruitment drives and activity camps, and to create new start-ups in many fields. A new Purdue-sponsored inner city high school will offer new avenues of long-term outreach with robotics focus, as well as a university-wide examination of robotics curriculum across 13 departments and 5 colleges where aspects of this work will be embraced.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of this project was a new generation of additive manufacturing instrument that combines form with function through the integration of printable sensing, printable computation, printable actuation, and printable software with printable structure to produce entirely new types of robotic materials and designer polymers. We call this “Form + Function 4-D Printing” (FF4DP) because it adds the dimension of functionality to the 3D fabrication process. The motivation for doing so is to revolutionize the design of smart products and to stimulate new innovations from the co-design research community.

This innovative new fabrication instrument allows designers to simultaneously synthesize new hybrid polymer materials while they design new products out of such new materials. The Form + Function 4D Printer allows non-experts to explore new material design, distributed sensing design, computational hardware and software design, distributed actuator design, and structural design through a "fail-fast" style of rapid prototyping that empowers them to invent new solutions by filling in the gaps in the designer's knowledge.

Imagine creating an entire smart product prototype, such as a robotic toy or a wearable health monitor, at the press of a button. Until now, this has not been possible. Creating a prototype of a smart product that combines electronic sensors with microprocessors, software, and aesthetic form traditionally requires a team of individual designers with individual skills. The Form + Function 4D Printer fills in the knowledge gaps of an individual designer to achieve new combinations of form and function.

The primary outcome is the combination of fused filament fabrication (FFF), which this project refers to as "solid extrusion," with direct ink writing (DIW), which this project refers to as "liquid extrusion." This enables the printing of alternate layers of structure with functionality. A series of customized methods of printing liquid polymer extrusions capable of producing non-silicon, polymer electronic components -- such as resistors, capacitors, and even transistors -- has been optimized and integrated with conventional methods of solid extrusion of polymer structure. In addition, non-polymer components, such as silicon RF electronics or ferrous materials, can be incorporated by pick-and-place technology. This allows circuit boards to be printed into the bulk of the structure with the necessary printed and placed electronic components to make them work. 

But creating sensors, algorithms and actuators requires expertise that may not exist all in one person. The project team established a format for "Intelligent Design Agents" (IDAs) that can help designers layout circuits or optimize sensor placement to achieve detailed results. The focus of this project was the development of the printer for FF4DP, including the facility enabling the incorporation of domain-specific IDAs for different applications. The full suite of IDAs representing different expertise will evolve over time.

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2024
Modified by: Richard M Voyles

Images (1 of )
  • A 4D Printer for Form and Function combines liquid ink printing with solid extrusion and pick-and-place of non-polymer components to yield multi-functional printed systems.
    Yuelin Deng
    Copyrighted
    Richard M Voyles
    Form + Function 4D Printing
  • The combination of printed actuation, printed sensors, printed circuitry, printed passive components and placed active components results in a fully functional robotic gripper.
    Yuelin Deng
    Copyrighted
    Richard M Voyles
    Printed robot gripper
  • Printing circuits, resistors and capacitors. Silicon devices can also be placed and encapsulated with the bulk material.
    Yuelin Deng
    Copyrighted
    Richard M Voyles
    Printing passive components
